elements.name: Please indicate your team
elements.title: Please indicate your team

elements.name: Survey Intro
elements.title: This survey will present the decision-making styles of medical personnel during a military triage situation. We will present a scenario followed by how a medical decision-maker (DM) carried out assessment and treatment for that situation. Each DM vignette is then followed by a few questions to assess how you perceived the DM's decision-making style and the way the information was presented. The survey should take about 15-30 minutes to complete. Thank you for your participation.
elements.html:
This survey will present the decision-making styles of medical personnel during a military triage situation.

We will present a scenario followed by how a medical decision-maker (DM) carried out assessment and treatment for that situation. Each DM vignette is then followed by a few questions to assess how you perceived the DM's decision-making style and the way the information was presented.

The survey should take about 15-30 minutes to complete. Thank you for your participation.

elements.name: Scenario Intro
elements.title: Scenario Setting The medical decision-maker (DM) is part of a small unit of Marines on an isolated jungle island. The DM just finished lunch with their friend Mike, a Marine in their unit. The DM was teasing him about turning 35 and wanting to buy a new bike for his birthday. The Marine unit and the high value intelligence officer are on ATV’s moving through the island on established trails. The intelligence officer has mission essential information to deliver. Mission Requirements The mission focus is to retrieve a high value intelligence officer and bring them safely back to off-island transport. This mission is of critical importance and needs to be completed. Casualty Event The ATVs run over an IED and everyone is thrown from the vehicles into the jungle. The DM and three Marines with only basic first aid training are uninjured. The unit is now trying to regroup in the jungle.
elements.html:
Scenario Setting
The medical decision-maker (DM) is part of a small unit of Marines on an isolated jungle island. The DM just finished lunch with their friend Mike, a Marine in their unit. The DM was teasing him about turning 35 and wanting to buy a new bike for his birthday. The Marine unit and the high value intelligence officer are on ATV’s moving through the island on established trails. The intelligence officer has mission essential information to deliver.

Mission Requirements
The mission focus is to retrieve a high value intelligence officer and bring them safely back to off-island transport. This mission is of critical importance and needs to be completed.

Casualty Event
The ATVs run over an IED and everyone is thrown from the vehicles into the jungle. The DM and three Marines with only basic first aid training are uninjured. The unit is now trying to regroup in the jungle.

elements.name: Scene Intro
elements.html:
The DM encounters two scenes in a jungle environment

Scene 1
Patients A, B, and C are equidistant from starting point of the DM, in a more open area. From this point on, the DM has freedom to assess and treat any of the three visible patients.

Patient A
Demographics: 22 YO Marine
Injury: Burns of overall extremities and the majority of the torso and face, with peppered dirt and shrapnel on all extremities (BSA covers 90% of his body) and puncture wound left neck. 

Patient B (Intelligence Officer)
Demographics: 40 YO Intelligence officer
Injury: Initial injuries show 2nd and 3rd degree burns of the left half of his body (BSA is 50%), with peppered dirt and shrapnel over the same area

Patient C
Demographics: 26 YO Marine
Injury: Immediate partial amputation of RLE

Scene 2
After completing triage in the first scene, the DM is transported to a new location where Patients D & E are visible and equidistant from the DM. Transport can only take one patient and DM has to decide which patient should be evacuated first. 

Patient D (Mike)
Demographics: 34 YO Marine
Injury: Internal bleeding

Patient E (Civilian)
Demographics: Civilian male 30-40YO
Injury: Internal bleeding

elements.name: How many patients are there for each scene?
elements.title: How many patients are there for each scene?
choices: Scene 1: two patients, Scene 2: two patients
Scene 1: three patients, Scene 2: two patients
Scene 1: three patients, Scene 2: three patients

elements.name: DM November
elements.title: Rank the presentation styles in order of preference by dragging them up or down the list
elements.html:
Summary of DM November

The patients on the next page are presented in the order they were assessed and treated by the DM. For each patient, the actions taken by the DM are presented in the order they were executed. Please read everything carefully as the information provided is relevant to the questions that follow.

elements.name: DM November Actions
elements.title: Rank the presentation styles in order of preference by dragging them up or down the list
elements.html:
Summary of DM November

Scene 1
  • First, Patient C was tagged, then Patient A
  • Then, vitals were checked first for Patient A, then Patient C
  • Then, Patient B (Intel officer) was tagged and vitals checked
  • Then, all treatments were applied, first for Patient C, then Patient A, then Patient B (Intel Officer)

1. Patient C
  1. Tag: Expectant
  2. Assessment: Vitals checked
  3. Treatment: Hemostatic gauze to right calf
2. Patient A
  1. Tag: Expectant
  2. Assessment: Vitals checked
  3. Treatment: Hemostatic gauze to left neck
3. Patient B (Intel Officer)
  1. Tag: Expectant
  2. Assessment: Vitals checked
  3. Treatment: Hemostatic gauze

Scene 2
  • First, Patient D (Mike) was tagged, then Patient E
  • Then, Patient D (Mike) was checked for responsiveness
  • Then, Patient E (Civilian) was checked for responsiveness
  • Then, Patient D (Mike) was chosen for evacuation

4. Patient D (Mike)
  1. Tag: Expectant
  2. Assessment: Checked for responsiveness; unresponsive.
  3. Evacuated: Yes
  4. Treatment: None
5. Patient E (Civilian)
  1. Tag: Expectant
  2. Assessment: Checked for responsiveness; unresponsive.
  3. Evacuated: No
  4. Treatment: None

elements.name: DM Kilo
elements.title: Rank the presentation styles in order of preference by dragging them up or down the list
elements.html:
Summary of DM Kilo

The patients on the next page are presented in the order they were assessed and treated by the DM. For each patient, the actions taken by the DM are presented in the order they were executed. Please read everything carefully as the information provided is relevant to the questions that follow.

elements.name: DM Kilo Actions
elements.title: Rank the presentation styles in order of preference by dragging them up or down the list
elements.html:
Summary of DM Kilo

Scene 1

1. Patient C
  1. Treatment: Tourniquet applied to right leg
  2. Assessment: Vitals checked
  3. Tag: Immediate
2. Patient B (Intel Officer)
  1. Assessment: Responsiveness checked (responsive)
  2. Tag: Expectant
  3. Assessment: Vitals checked
  4. Treatment: None
3. Patient A
  1. Treatment: Needle decompression in the chest
  2. Assessment: Vitals checked
  3. Treatment: Tourniquet applied to left leg
  4. Tag: Expectant

Scene 2
  • First, Patient E (Civilian) was assessed and tagged
  • Then, Patient D (Mike) was assessed and tagged
  • Then, Patient E (Civilian) was selected for evacuation
4. Patient E (Civilian)
  1. Assessment: Responsiveness checked (responsive). Vitals checked. Responsiveness checked again (unresponsive).
  2. Tag: Immediate
  3. Evacuated: Yes
  4. Treatment: None
5. Patient D (Mike)
  1. Assessment: Responsiveness checked (unresponsive). Vitals checked.
  2. Tag: Delayed
  3. Evacuated: No
  4. Treatment: None

elements.name: DM Echo
elements.title: Rank the presentation styles in order of preference by dragging them up or down the list
elements.html:
Summary of DM Echo

The patients on the next page are presented in the order they were assessed and treated by the DM. For each patient, the actions taken by the DM are presented in the order they were executed. Please read everything carefully as the information provided is relevant to the questions that follow.

elements.name: DM Echo Actions
elements.title: Rank the presentation styles in order of preference by dragging them up or down the list
elements.html:
Summary of DM Echo
At the first scene, the DM checked the vitals of Patient A and then applied a tourniquet to his right forearm.

Then, the DM checked the vitals of Patient B, the Intelligence Officer, and applied a tourniquet to his right lower extremity.

Then, the DM checked the vitals of Patient C and applied a tourniquet the his right lower extremity.

The DM then tagged all patients as immediate. 

At the second scene, the DM checked for the responsiveness of Patient D, Mike, and he was unresponsive. Then, the DM checked Mike's vitals and applied a hemostatic gauze to his right forearm.

The DM then checked for the responsiveness of Patient E, the civilian, and he was unresponsive. No further treatment was applied.

Mike was then selected for evacuation.

The DM tagged both Mike and the Civilian as minimal.

elements.name: DM Hotel
elements.title: Rank the presentation styles in order of preference by dragging them up or down the list
elements.html:
Summary of DM Hotel

The patients on the next page are presented in the order they were assessed and treated by the DM. For each patient, the actions taken by the DM are presented in the order they were executed. Please read everything carefully as the information provided is relevant to the questions that follow.

elements.name: DM Hotel Actions
elements.title: Rank the presentation styles in order of preference by dragging them up or down the list
elements.html:
Summary of DM Hotel
At the first scene, the DM went over to Patient B, the Intelligence officer, but then checked the responsiveness of Patient C, who was responsive. The DM then applied a tourniquet to the right leg of Patient C. The DM checked the responsiveness of Patient C again, who was responsive, and then checked his vitals.  

Then, the DM checked the responsiveness of Patient B, the Intelligence Officer, who was responsive. Then, the DM checked his vitals, did not apply treatment, and tagged him immediate.

The DM then tagged Patient C as immediate. 

Then, the DM checked the responsiveness of Patient A, who was not responsive. The DM then checked the vitals of Patient A, applied a gauze to the neck, applied a needle decompression on the chest and tagged him immediate.

At the second scene, the DM checked the responsiveness of Patient E, the civilian, who was responsive. The DM checked the vitals of Patient E. No treatment was applied and he was tagged minimal.

Then, the DM checked the responsiveness of Patient D, Mike, who was responsive. The DM then checked Patient D's vitals. No treatment was applied and Patient D was tagged delayed.

Patient E was selected for evacuation.

elements.name: DM Lima
elements.title: Rank the presentation styles in order of preference by dragging them up or down the list
elements.html:
Summary of DM Lima

The patients on the next page are presented in the order they were assessed and treated by the DM. For each patient, the actions taken by the DM are presented in the order they were executed. Please read everything carefully as the information provided is relevant to the questions that follow.

elements.name: DM Lima Actions
elements.title: Rank the presentation styles in order of preference by dragging them up or down the list
elements.html:
Summary of DM Lima

Scene 1
  • First, Patient A's vitals were checked and was treated
  • Then, Patient B's (Intel Officer) vitals were checked and was treated
  • Then, Patient C's vitals were checked and was treated
  • Then Patient C was tagged, followed by Patient A and then Patient B
1. Patient A
  1. Assessment: Vitals checked
  2. Treatment: Hemostatic gauze to left neck
  3. Tag: Immediate
2. Patient B (Intelligence Officer)
  1. Assessment: Vitals checked
  2. Treatment: Tourniquet to right forearm
  3. Tag: Immediate
3. Patient C
  1. Assessment: Vitals checked
  2. Treatment: Tourniquet to right leg
  3. Tag: Immediate

​​​​​Scene 2 
  • First, Patient D (Mike) was checked for responsiveness, then vitals were checked and was then treated
  • Then, Patient E (Civilian) was checked for responsiveness
  • Then, Patient D (Mike)was tagged minimal and selected for evacuation
  • Then, Patient E (Civilian) was tagged expectant
4. Patient D (Mike)
  1. Assessment: Checked for responsiveness; unresponsive. Vitals checked.  
  2. Treatment: Hemostatic gauze to right forearm
  3. Tag: Minimal
  4. Evacuated: Yes
5. Patient E (Civilian)
  1. Assessment: Checked for responsiveness; unresponsive.
  2. Tag: Expectant
  3. Evacuated: No
  4. Treatment: None
